parts.name: overview
parts.prose:
FedRAMP Key Security Indicators summarize the capabilities that satisfy FedRAMP security requirements aligned to NIST SP 800-53 controls, providing an abstraction layer that is simpler to approach and assess. Each Key Security Indicator includes critical security capabilities that must be met and validated. These capabilities are designed to provide a concrete approach to evaluating cloud security risks that can often be automatically derived from technical configurations and resolved to true or false.

Key Security Indicators are engineered to address critical limitations in existing security assessment approaches:

- Simplified capabilities: Reduce lengthy and complex security compliance to clear, actionable, capability-based standards
- Automation-Friendly: Eliminate reliance on narrative to create a foundation for future automated security assessment processes
- Flexible Implementation: Enable private innovation to design different methods for validation

Although Key Security Indicators are designed to produce final validations that are true or false, the minimum expectations for validation and assessment will require cloud service providers and third party assessment organizations to provide reasonable evidence supporting the final validation.

To maximize innovation, this standard does not propose validation, evidence, or assessment expectations for Key Security Indicators. Instead, minimum expectations for validation, evidence, and assessment will be determined during active FedRAMP 20x pilots in collaboration with cloud service providers, third party assessment organizations, and federal agencies.

All FedRAMP 20x packages submitted for assessment based on these standards must be in a machine-readable format that can be regenerated on demand.

This release includes the Key Security Indicators that must be addressed to meet security requirements for FedRAMP Low authorization for cloud service offerings that meet the following eligibility criteria:

1. Deployed on an existing FedRAMP authorized cloud service offering
2. Using primarily cloud-native services from the host provider
3. Using only FedRAMP authorized external services
4. Service is provided only via the public internet (browser and/or APIs)
5. Has completed a SOC 2 Type 2 audit or federal agency ATO process within the last 12 months

#

parts.name: overview
parts.prose: A secure cloud service offering will use cloud native architecture and design principles to enforce and enhance the Confidentiality, Integrity and Availability of the system.

parts.name: statement
item
parts.prose: Have denial of service (DoS) protection

parts.name: item
parts.prose: Configure firewalls/proxy servers to limit inbound and outbound traffic

parts.name: item
parts.prose: Use immutable containers and serverless functions with strictly defined functionality and privileges

parts.name: item
parts.prose: Design systems as logically segmented micro-services to minimize the attack surface and lateral movement if compromised

parts.name: item
parts.prose: Use cloud native virtual networks and related capabilities to enforce logical traffic flow controls

parts.name: item
parts.prose: Execute continuous scanning of cloud native system components

parts.name: item
parts.prose: Use high availability design principles to maximize uptime
Cloud service providers MUST:

parts.name: overview
parts.prose: A secure cloud service offering will enforce the use of approved cryptography, continuously verify component integrity, and restrict access to external services.

parts.name: statement
item
parts.prose: Harden and review network and system configurations

parts.name: item
parts.prose: Encrypt all network traffic

parts.name: item
parts.prose: Encrypt all federal and sensitive information at rest

parts.name: item
parts.prose: Manage configuration centrally

parts.name: item
parts.prose: Enforce system and component integrity through cryptographic means

parts.name: item
parts.prose: Use a key management capability to execute regular rotation of digital keys

parts.name: item
parts.prose: Use a consistent, risk-informed approach for applying security patches
Cloud service providers MUST:

parts.name: overview
parts.prose: A secure cloud service offering will enforce the use of approved cryptography, continuously verify component integrity, and restrict access to external services.

parts.name: statement
item
parts.prose: Enforce phishing-resistant multi-factor authentication (MFA)

parts.name: item
parts.prose: Enforce strong passwords

parts.name: item
parts.prose: Use secure API authentication methods via industry standard protocols

parts.name: item
parts.prose: Use a least-privileged, role-based, and just-in-time security model
Cloud service providers MUST:

parts.name: overview
parts.prose: A secure cloud service offering will monitor, log, and audit all important events, activity, and changes.

parts.name: statement
item
parts.prose: Operate a Security Information and Event Management (SIEM) system for centralized, tamper-resistant event, activity, and change logging

parts.name: item
parts.prose: Regularly review and audit logs

parts.name: item
parts.prose: Rapidly detect and remediate or mitigate vulnerabilities

parts.name: item
parts.prose: Perform authenticated vulnerability scanning on publicly accessible components

parts.name: item
parts.prose: Perform Infrastructure as Code (IaC) and configuration scanning

parts.name: item
parts.prose: Centrally track and prioritize the remediation of identified vulnerabilities
Cloud service providers MUST:

parts.name: overview
parts.prose: A secure cloud service provider will ensure that all system changes are properly documented, and configuration baselines are updated accordingly.

parts.name: statement
item
parts.prose: Log and monitor system modifications

parts.name: item
parts.prose: Execute changes though redeployment of version controlled immutable resources rather than direct modification wherever possible

parts.name: item
parts.prose: Implement automated testing and validation of changes prior to deployment

parts.name: item
parts.prose: Have a documented change management procedure

parts.name: item
parts.prose: Evaluate the risk and potential impact of any change
Cloud service providers MUST:

parts.name: overview
parts.prose: A secure cloud service offering will have intentional, organized, universal guidance for how every asset, including personnel, is secured.

parts.name: statement
item
parts.prose: Have an up-to-date asset inventory or code defining all deployed assets

parts.name: item
parts.prose: Have policies outlining their security objectives

parts.name: item
parts.prose: Maintain a vulnerability disclosure program

parts.name: item
parts.prose: Build security considerations into the Software Development Lifecycle (SDLC) and aligning with Secure By Design principles

parts.name: item
parts.prose: Document methods used to automatically evaluate implementations

parts.name: item
parts.prose: Have a dedicated staff and budget for security
Cloud service providers MUST:

parts.name: overview
parts.prose: A secure cloud service offering will understand, monitor, and manage supply chain risks from third party services or components.

parts.name: statement
item
parts.prose: Regularly confirm that services storing Federal information are all FedRAMP authorized and securely configured

parts.name: item
parts.prose: Identify and prioritize potential supply chain risks

parts.name: item
parts.prose: Obtain a Software Bill of Materials (SBOM) for third party commercial software components

parts.name: item
parts.prose: Confirm that third party information resources have a Secure Software Development Attestation with CISA

parts.name: item
parts.prose: Implement zero trust design principles
Cloud service providers MUST:

parts.name: overview
parts.prose: A secure cloud service provider will continuously educate their employees on cybersecurity measures, testing them regularly to ensure their knowledge is satisfactory.

parts.name: statement
item
parts.prose: Ensure all employees receive security awareness training

parts.name: item
parts.prose: Require role-specific training for high risk roles
Cloud service providers MUST:

parts.name: overview
parts.prose: A secure cloud service offering will maintain, test, and execute effective Incident Response Plans for routine incidents such as vulnerability discovery, abnormal activity detection, and exfiltration of data.

parts.name: statement
item
parts.prose: Define Recovery Time Objective (RTO) and Recovery Point Objective (RPO)

parts.name: item
parts.prose: Perform system backups aligned with the RTO and RPO

parts.name: item
parts.prose: Test the capability to recover from incidents and contingencies

parts.name: item
parts.prose: Report incidents according to federal requirements

parts.name: item
parts.prose: Maintain a log of incidents and periodically review past incidents for patterns or vulnerabilities

parts.name: item
parts.prose: Measure Mean Time To Detect (MTTD) and Mean Time To Resolution (MTTR) for incidents

metadata.title: FedRAMP RFC-0006 20x Phase One Key Security Indicators
metadata.remarks: This catalog represents the DRAFT key security indicators (KSIs) published by the Federal Risk and Authorization Management Program (FedRAMP) Program Management Office (PMO) as a suggested starting point for community engagement. The KSIs are subject to change pending community feedback.
